title: PG&E Makes Final Push to Stay in Charge of Chapter 11
summary: Embattled utility owner says it can find its own way out of bankruptcy, but creditors disagree. summary: Investors are down on fracking firms, even as the companies pump record volumes of oil and gas. American shale companies have never pumped more. They have never been loved less.

title: San Francisco, Santa Clara County File Suit to Block Rule on Green Cards
summary: Plaintiffs say move to deny permanent residence to legal immigrants who draw from social programs is unlawful. San Francisco and neighboring Santa Clara County filed suit against the Trump administration, challenging the government's move to deny permanent residence to legal immigrants who use certain public-assistance programs or bar entry for those deemed likely to do so.

title: The 'Public-Charge' Ploy
summary: A new rule looks like another effort to limit legal immigration.. President Trump in his better moments has said he wants, and the U.S. needs, more legal immigrants. But that's hard to square with the way his Administration is now trying to curtail legal immigration under the pretext of preventing America from becoming a welfare magnet.

title: A Tactical Tariff Retreat
summary: A tacit admission that trade wars aren't cost-free to consumers.. If President Trump wants more proof that financial markets are hostage to his China trade war, he received it on Tuesday. The White House announced it will postpone part of its recently announced third round of 10% tariffs on Chinese goods until Dec. 15, and stocks rallied while bond yields rose.

title: The Hong Kong Stakes for Trump
summary: He needs to warn China about the damage from a crackdown.. The stakes are rising in Hong Kong, as clashes between pro-democracy protesters and the local government backed by China are escalating. The damage could be global if President Xi Jinping orders a bloody crackdown, and President Trump should be warning the Chinese President not to do it.

title: Violent Young Men, Here and Abroad
summary: In understanding its mass-shooting problem, America can learn a few things from recent Mideastern history.. America's young male killers, who glory in indiscriminate slaughter, are a Western eruption of a larger phenomenon. What's often called "stateless terrorism," or deadly extremism by individuals and groups, could as accurately be described as a male crackup. This convulsion has been most acute in the Muslim Middle East, where modern authoritarianism has bulldozed the past, freeing young men from once-powerful social constraints and exposing them to a radical religious rebellion. America-the relentless engine of innovation and change-now also faces an outbreak of disconnected young men murdering exuberantly.

title: The Smear Campaign Against Charters
summary: Far from being 'resegregated,' some of our schools are actually majority-minority-and that's by parents' free choice.. Leland, N.C.

title: How Uber Makes Its Drivers Pay
summary: The firm's reported costs don't include the cars' lost value: almost $11 billion.. Uber lost $5.24 billion in the second quarter this year and seems to have no clear path to profitability. But even that loss is understated, because a substantial part of the expense is not included in Uber's income statement and is instead pushed onto drivers: the wear and tear the job puts on their cars.

title: Making Money Is a Patriotic Act
summary: The businesses we created help Americans by providing jobs, growth, goods and services.. The two of us are quite rich. We have earned more money than we could have imagined and more than we can spend on ourselves, our children and grandchildren. These days getting rich off a profitable business is regarded as almost sinister. But we have nothing to apologize for, and we don't think the government should have more of our profits.

title: I Get a Kick Out of . . . Who?
summary: Porter? Gershwin? At least my 18-year-old student knew Sinatra.. It was my last lesson with my 18-year-old student-let's call him Joe. In a few weeks he would head off to start his freshman year in college. He planned to study business. His father had hired me over the summer to teach Joe how to trade stocks using charts and technical analysis. I acquired this skill-through blood and suffering-about 12 years ago as a way of supplementing my unpredictable income as a freelance writer.

title: 'The Plateau' Review: A Culture of Selflessness
summary: An isolated community in southern France showed what could be done to protect victims of persecution during World War II.. It was in the spring of 1942, as the Germans occupying France began rounding up Jews for deportation, that the inhabitants of the remote Vivarais-Lignon plateau opened their doors to refugees fleeing capture. Situated in the Massif Central region of southern France, high in the mountains and cut off from the rest of the country by thick snow during the winter months, the Vivarais-Lignon had a long tradition of resistance. In the 16th century, it was a stronghold for the Huguenots during France's wars of religion. Now, as the Nazis and the Vichy government intensified their own persecutions, Catholics, Protestants and Darbyists-followers of John Darby, a 19th-century English preacher-offered sanctuary to Jews. Some hid them in barns and attics; others pretended that they were family members. Many of these saviors were dour, silent people, accustomed to hard lives, who shared a belief that sheltering strangers was not only important but fundamental to who they were.

title: New York City Councilwoman Wants Patient Advocate Office
summary: Similar patient-advocate offices already exist in California and Connecticut. A bill set to be introduced Wednesday in the New York City Council seeks to create a new office to receive and report on complaints against health-care facilities and providers.

summary: So far at the Joyce Theater Ballet Festival, astute looks at the Royal Ballet's past have been the standouts..

title: We Can Assimilate Immigrants if the Left Allows
summary: Mr. Riley's point about shared values and a cultural whole that is bigger than the sum of its parts is well taken, but America now has a values gap that is far wider than any income gap.. Jason L. Riley says that I see "European-style nationalist impulses as something conservatives should harness rather than discourage" ("Can America Still Assimilate Immigrants?," Upward Mobility, Aug. 7). I have never said, or remotely suggested, any such thing. The whole point of nationalism is that each nation is responsible for charting its own course. All of my proposals for U.S. national conservatism have been specifically, emphatically rooted in distinctive American ideals, traditions and circumstances. To single me out as one who is "channeling France" and "would have America follow Europe's lead" is preposterous.

title: Rat Control Functions Properly in California
summary: AB 1788 clearly protects public health. It contains an exemption for any type of public health emergency and allows for at least 185 other products to be used to control rats.. Regarding your editorial "California Goes to the Rats" (Aug. 8): California Assembly Bill 1788 is a narrowly targeted bill that restricts use of the second-generation anticoagulant rat poisons that are taking a heavy toll on the state's wildlife, including many threatened and endangered species. For the past several decades, California Fish & Wildlife has been collecting data on mortality and illnesses caused by anticoagulant rat poisons. The data and the associated necropsy reports show a very clear link between anticoagulants and wildlife mortality and disease. Anticoagulants kill many nontarget species including eagles, owls, hawks, bobcats and mountain lions, causing them to bleed to death (the same way they kill rats). If these poisons don't kill the animals outright, they can cause other serious illnesses, such as mange, that ultimately lead to death.

title: Candy Retailer Lolli & Pops Files for Bankruptcy
summary: San Francisco-based retailer, whose main venue is shopping malls, was locked out of 10% of its stores last week. Lolli & Pops Inc., a San Francisco-based candy retailer with 69 U.S. shops, has filed for bankruptcy after being locked out of about 10% of its stores last week.

title: It's That Short Distance That Makes Life So Sweet
summary: We resolved the question by each building one-half of the same duplex in a 55-plus gated community.. My significant other, John, and I are the kind of a couple discussed in your article "More Older Couples Stay Together by Living Apart" (Life & Arts, July 29). Both alone and in our 70s, we've been together for nearly 10 years, living in two separate houses, trying to figure out how to grow old together but apart. We resolved the question by each building one-half of the same duplex in a 55-plus gated community. Thus, we'll be as unrelated financially and legally as next-door neighbors, but we will live with just a common wall between us, share a backyard for our dogs and enjoy all the amenities of being part of the same community. We are also avid RVers, so a lock-and-leave community is perfect for when we are away.

title: Sports and Politics Should Play in Different Arenas
summary: Sports and entertainment exist precisely to take us away from our everyday lives and provide an escape from reality.. I am a huge fan of Jason Gay and read his column whether it is a sport I follow or not because I know he will always make me smile. I was terribly disappointed to see him dip into the political realm with his piece "The Problem with Sticking to Sports" (Sports, Aug. 6). I am one of those people who believes that both sports and entertainment exist precisely to take us away from our everyday lives and provide an escape from reality. I am slowly retreating from both entities as their participants become more and more interested in using those forums as platforms for their opinions instead of what they are actually being paid to do.

title: The Sierra Club Certainly Has Standing in Wall Case
summary: No court-not even the Supreme Court-ever suggested the Sierra Club lacks standing or that our members face harm from the construction of a 30-foot wall on the lands they use, treasure and successfully petitioned Congress to protect.. Your editorial "The National Injunction Dysfunction" (July 29) assumes the Sierra Club has shown no clear injury from President Trump's illegal wall, and therefore has no standing to sue. No court-not even the Supreme Court-ever suggested the Sierra Club lacks standing, and the Trump administration itself conceded early on in litigation that our members face harm from the construction of a 30-foot wall on the lands they use, treasure and successfully petitioned Congress to protect.

title: What Will Socialists Do When Capitalists Are Gone?
summary: The Democratic Socialists of America were so anxious to keep tweeting during the proceedings, they couldn't be persuaded to turn off the their smartphones.. Socialist millennials at the national convention of Democratic Socialists of America were so anxious to keep tweeting during the proceedings, they couldn't be persuaded to turn off the phones they won't have once they have rid the country of capitalism.

title: Can I Wear Shorts as Short as John Wayne's?
summary: Men's shorts with eensy inseams have lately come back in style, recalling the startlingly small hot pants that "the Duke" wore back in the day. title: Can Climbing Everest Help Sell a Handbag?
summary: Top luxury brands have been compelled to look beyond traditional advertising-driven in part by consumers' desire for companies with a sense of mission. This spring, the Swiss fashion house Bally sponsored a mission to remove garbage from the slopes of Mount Everest, even in the so-called Death Zone above 26,000 feet. In September, Italian watch manufacturer Panerai will take about 15 customers diving off the island of Moorea in French Polynesia, hoping to catch sight of whales. title: 'My Baby Monitor Is Haunted': Tales of Parental Fright
summary: Parents catch ghostly images near their babies; 'I could not go to sleep that night.'. Natalie Wallace was lying in bed one night more than a month ago when she glanced at her Cocoon Cam baby monitor. She noticed splotches of pink and purple all around the baby's bassinet. The colors are supposed to indicate motion, but her baby was in a deep sleep.

title: World Trade Center Still Loses Money
summary: Port Authority had envisioned 'peace dividend' benefiting bridges, tunnels and airports. New York City showed resilience when it rebuilt the World Trade Center after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, but the project was also supposed to generate profits that could go toward bridges, tunnels and airports.

title: Bond Yields Make Stocks Hard to Ignore
summary: Nearly 60% of S&P 500 stocks offer dividend yield of at least 1.7%, beating 10-year U.S. Treasurys. A plunge in bond yields has left investors with few alternatives to stocks.

title: Researchers Hack Into Industrial Equipment Thought to Be Secure
summary: Encryption problem with a Siemens machine highlights industrial security challenges. Researchers have warned Siemens AG that the encryptions for a widely used piece of its industrial equipment, thought to be safer than rival machines, could open up infrastructure companies and factories to cyberattacks.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Brinker Bets Delivery Will Drive Sales Growth
summary: Company forecasts same-store sales growth of 1.75% to 2.5% for fiscal 2020. Brinker International Inc., parent of Chili's Grill & Bar and Maggiano's Little Italy, is betting delivery will help it offset weaker demand for casual dining.

title: RealReal's Revenue Soars as Its Loss Widens
summary: Shares of online luxury reseller surge after hours. The booming market for secondhand goods isn't immune from the pressures facing retailers that sell new products.

title: Hong Kong Cancels More Flights After Protests Hit Airport
summary: Thousands of demonstrators fill airport to condemn police handling of long-running protests. HONG KONG-A large crowd of antigovernment demonstrators shut down Hong Kong's airport and stranded thousands of passengers, as officials in Beijing responded to the weekend's violent clashes by saying they saw signs of terrorism emerging in the protests.

title: Some Stock Prices Delayed as Glitch Hits NYSE-Run Data Feed
summary: Issue marks the latest in a series of tech problems for exchange. A key stock-market data feed run by the New York Stock Exchange suffered a technical glitch on Monday, leading to delays in releasing the end-of-day values of the Dow Jones Industrial Average and the S&P 500.

title: Trucker Celadon Hires Former Swift Transportation CEO to Assist With Turnaround Efforts
summary: The carrier has engaged DPX Consulting to oversee its main trucking unit. Freight transportation company Celadon Group Inc. is bringing on the former leader of trucking giant Swift Transportation Co. to help overhaul its truckload division after securing new backing to help its turnaround efforts.

title: Dayton Gunman's Friend Bought Body Armor, Authorities Allege
summary: Ethan Kollie, a friend of Connor Betts, has been charged with lying on federal firearms forms. Federal prosecutors in Ohio allege a friend of Connor Betts purchased body armor and gun accessories that were used in the mass shooting that killed nine people this month in Dayton.

title: New York City Considers Lifting Hostel Ban
summary: City council bill pushes to legalize budget hotels after nearly decadelong ban. New York City could legalize hostels under a bill set to be introduced this week in the city council, the second attempt to reauthorize the budget hotels after a state law made them illegal.

title: Trump Confirms Missile Exploded During Testing in Russia
summary: At least seven people were killed in an accident Thursday during a test of a nuclear-powered engine in the northwestern Arkhangelsk region of Russia. WASHINGTON-President Trump confirmed reports that an advanced nuclear-powered cruise missile had exploded during testing in Russia and said the U.S. was "learning much" from the incident.
